III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Two youth AWOL’d from the facility on 3/14/2025. The foster care
agency was notified 2 hours after the AWOL.
Investigation Interviews:
Agency Director was interviewed by phone on 4/18/25. Agency
Director reported being notified of Youth B’s AWOL approximately
two hours after Youth B exited the building. Agency Director
reported she believes the facility also called law enforcement and
that facility staff were searching for Youth A and Youth B. Agency
Director reported the facility stayed in constant contact with the
servicing foster care agency. Agency Director reported Youth B
was located the following day by Detroit police.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 4/16/2025.
Youth B reported she did not wish to talk about Youth A because it
made her sad to think about. Youth B reported she and Youth A
planned to leave the facility together and go someplace. Youth B
reported she was gone half of a day. When asked about the day
she left with Youth A including the plan to leave the building, who
was around, and what took place, Youth B declined to respond
and asked to end the conversation.
Youth A was interviewed at a child advocacy center on 4/30/25 by
Child Advocate. Consultant was not allowed to ask additional
questions, so the names of the staff Youth A discussed during her
interview are unknown. Youth A reported she planned to leave the
facility and told people she was leaving. Youth A reported she
planned to leave with Youth B. Youth A reported the doors unlock
if you pull the fire alarm. Youth A reported wearing multiple layers
of clothing on purpose to bring them with her. Youth A reported
staff tried to follow her and Youth B when they left the building, but
they were “large” and could not run. Youth A reported choosing to
go when “large” staff were working so they could not run after
them.
2

Case Manager was interviewed via video conference on
5/2/2025. Case Manager reported she is the assigned foster care
worker for Youth A. Case Manager reported Youth A informed her
on 3/14/25 of her plan to AWOL from the facility the following
week. Case Manager reported she informed the therapist at the
facility of the potential AWOL. Case Manager reported the facility
contacted her by phone multiple times the same day Youth A went
AWOL. Case Manager reported there were missed calls on her
work phone from the facility after working hours and she found out
upon returning to work Youth A had gone AWOL.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/9/25.
Supervisor reported Youth A was on truancy observation and Staff
3 was aware that Youth A may AWOL. Supervisor reported if the
fire alarm is pulled the team leader present is to deactivate it and
reset it so the doors will lock again. Supervisor reported while on a
truancy observation, Youth should always be monitored.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/9/25. Staff
1 reported not being present at the time that Youth A and Youth B
went AWOL. Staff 1 reported Youth A had been on a truancy
observation due to awareness that she was going to try to run
because she was telling people that she was going to. Staff 1
reported truancy observation entails watching the youth and
documenting every 15 minutes what the youth is doing. Staff 1
reported no awareness of Youth B being on truancy observation.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/9/25. Staff
2 reported working the shift prior to Youth A and Youth B going
AWOL. Staff 2 reported observing Youth A and Youth B
whispering to each other at which time Staff 2 inquired with Youth
A and Youth B what they were whispering about. Staff 2 reported
noting the interaction to the shift following hers.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/9/25. Staff
3 reported Youth A and Youth B were the only two youth in the
building as they were not able to go with the rest of the youth for
poetry night due to being on special observations. Staff 3 reported
she and Staff 4 were present with Youth A and Youth B. Staff 3
reported Staff 4 was in the back with Youth A and Youth B and
Youth A went into the bathroom. Staff 3 reported Youth B then
went to the fire alarm next to the kitchenette and pulled it. Staff 3
reported going to the alarm to disarm it so the doors could lock
again. Staff 3 reported while working on the alarm she inquired
with Youth B why she pulled it at which time she saw Youth A nod
at Youth B, and they both took off running to the front door. Staff 3
reported telling Staff 4 to follow them. Staff 3 reported seeing
Youth A outside going over the hill. Staff 3 reported Staff 4
3

followed outside to look for them. Staff 3 reported she notified
Supervisor, Consumer Right’s Officer, Director, and called the
police. Staff 3 reported providing Youth A and Youth B’s
information to police when they arrived. Staff 3 reported during
truancy observation, staff are to document what the youth is doing
every 15 minutes and any youth on this watch cannot leave the
building to participate in activities.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/9/25. Staff
4 reported upon arrival to her shift Youth B had her coat on so
Staff 4 asked her why. Staff 4 reported Youth B told her she was
always cold. Staff 4 reported Youth A and Youth B were in the
building while everyone else went to an event because they were
on observations. Staff 4 reported Youth A and Youth B asked to
go by Youth A’s bedroom, so she went over with them and sat.
Staff 4 reported Youth A asked to go in her room to get her
mother’s picture because she does not go anywhere without it.
Staff 4 reported asking Youth A why she needed it at that time and
where was she going that she would need to take it. Staff 4
reported Youth A told her she was having a hard day, so she
wanted it. Staff 4 reported unlocking the bedroom for Youth A to
retrieve the photo. Staff 4 reported when she turned back from
relocking the door Youth A had moved through the door between
the hallway and the living area, and the fire alarm was sounding.
Staff 4 reported not being aware yet if it was a real emergency, so
she inquired on what was happening, while observing Youth B to
have her hands over her ears. Staff 4 reported Staff 3 informed
her Youth B had pulled the fire alarm and went to turn it off. Staff 4
reported asking Youth B why she pulled the alarm then both Youth
A and Youth B ran past her and to the front door. Staff 4 reported
Youth A attempted to open the door multiple times by pushing the
button and was able to open it after a few tries. Staff 4 reported
following behind Youth A and Youth B and could still see Youth B
but could no longer see Youth A from outside the front door. Staff
4 reported she followed Youth A and Youth B out of the building
and towards the back of the next building until she could no longer
see either Youth A or Youth B. Staff 4 reported she did not have a
walkie, and her phone was not working. Staff 4 reported that she
did not have a walkie as this was not her typical building, she was
working in, so she did not know where they were. Staff 4 reported
going back to get a walkie and went back out but could not see
them.
Video Reviewed:
• Video footage of facility building on 3/14/2025 beginning at
5:40 PM shows Staff 4 locking the bathroom door in the
hallway while Youth B runs to the other side of the building
where the fire alarm is located. Youth A is shown to follow
4

Youth B and faces her while Youth B has one had on the
wall by the fire alarm. At 5:41 PM, Youth A gives a thumbs
up to Youth B who then pulls the fire alarm. Staff 4 walks
through the same door to enter the hallway Youth A and
Youth B are in while Youth B runs, covering her ears. Staff
3 enters the hallway and moves to the fire alarm. Youth B
walks past Staff 3 and Staff 4 towards the front entrance
with Youth A following behind. Youth A gets to the door
with Youth B and push the first door open and enter the
foyer, then appear to exit the main entrance door at 5:41
PM. The frame of the video does not have visual of the
door opening and closing. Staff 3 enters the foyer and goes
past the frame where the main entry door is at 3 minutes
and 52 seconds into the video, and reenters at 3 minutes
and 56 seconds, holding a cell phone, grabs a walkie and
exits the building again.
Documents Reviewed:
- Incident Report #3119 dated 3/14/2025 authored by
Staff 4 documents Youth B pulled the fire alarm at
approximately 5:30pm. Youth A nodded to Youth B and the
two of them exiting the building after two unsuccessful
attempts to open the door. IR states Staff 4 called out to
Youth A and Youth B with no response. IR states police
were called at approximately 6:15 PM, Youth A’s Foster
Care Worker was contacted at 6:44 PM, Youth B’s Foster
Care Worker was contacted at 6:52 PM, and a missing
person’s report was filed. IR states that police arrived at
approximately 7:30pm.
- Absent without legal permission (AWOLP) POL-005-022
states reasonable efforts must be made to return a youth
who has attempted to leave without authorization. Policy
states the facility must make proper notifications within 1
hour and documented accordingly. The Supervisor/Team
Leader/Therapist will also notify the client’s
parent(s)/guardian if appropriate, as well as the referral
worker (if applicable) and police department. All
notifications must be completed within one hour and
documented in the incident report accordingly. Policy
further states all staff exiting the school or any unit in
pursuit of an AWOLP must have a working walkie-talkie or
cell phone on their person for proper communication with
the Supervisor.
- Client Observation POL-005-020 states observation
status requires 1 to 1 staffing with 100% observation. 100%
observation monitoring includes staff always remaining with
the youth and documenting their actions or behaviors every
5

15 minutes minimally unless determined otherwise by the
treatment team.
- Truancy Observation Plan regarding Youth A documents
Youth A being on 15 minute observation status beginning
2/12/2025.
- Staff 3’s Employee File documents she has two
disciplinary actions, unrelated to this investigation. Staff 3
was trained on child safety planning between January-May
2025.
- Staff 4’s Employee File documents one verbal warning,
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 4 was trained on shifts,
roles and program overview between November 2024-May
2025.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as per interviews conducted, video
footage reviewed, and documentation reviewed, the facility’s
policy was not followed.
The facility’s policy states all notifications of AWOLP must occur
within 1 hour. According to video footage reviewed, Youth A and
Youth B went AWOL at 5:41 pm as Staff 4 lost sight of them at
that time. According to the facility’s incident report, Youth A’s
Foster Care Worker was contacted at 6:44 PM and Youth B’s
Foster Care Worker was contacted at 6:52 PM. Neither of these
are within an hour of the youth going AWOLP.
Additionally, Staff 4 admitted she exited the building without a
walkie talkie or working phone. Per the agency ‘s AWOLP policy,
all staff exiting a building in pursuit of an AWOLP must have a
working walkie-talkie or cell phone on their person for proper
communication. There was knowledge Youth A was likely going to
go AWOLP as she was on a Truancy Observation Plan, so staff
should have been prepared to act and follow the AWOLP policy.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• The facility should ensure all staff working in a building they
are not normally assigned to have access to and
knowledge of where all required items (i.e. walkie talkie)
are located.
• The facility should incorporate truancy observation
information into their AWOLP procedures and AWOLP
training. For example, throughout this video and interviews
conducted, it was clear the youth were planning to go
AWOL, but staff were not diligent in recognizing or acting
on those signs (i.e. youth wearing multiple layers of clothing
including coats, Youth A getting her mother’s picture
because she can’t leave anywhere without it, youth
insisting on being on one end of the building, etc.).
6

Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
